Award.AwardTitle: SHB: Small: Collaborative Research: Electronic Textiles for Ambulatory Health Monitoring

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: Ambulatory health monitoring has been demonstrated to provide significant benefits to patients in a number of studies. The biggest promise for improved results for patients lies in the long-term, ambulatory monitoring of patients with chronic illnesses to help doctors and patients identify health issues before they reach a crisis stage. This project pursues the design of garments for ambulatory health monitoring that have the look and feel of every day clothing, together with an approach to monitoring that removes some of the barriers to patient compliance by automatically annotating physiological data with activities and motions, collecting data only during specific conditions, and having minimal impact on daily routine. The intellectual merits lie in the algorithms, design methodologies, and evaluation methodologies that enable wear-and-forget garments for ambulatory health monitoring. The approach developed by this project uses a computationally intensive pose estimation algorithm that automatically adapts a more computationally efficient algorithm for activity classification. This project addresses the challenges of providing garments that look and feel like everyday clothing by developing design and evaluation methodologies for incorporating fiber-based sensors into garments. These have significant advantages over discrete sensors by being woven or sewn into the fabric, covering much larger areas of a garment, and draping naturally. The broader impacts of the research lie in the potential to remove barriers that prevent the effective use of ambulatory health monitoring to improve the quality of life for patients and their families.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sensing the body unobtrusively and comfortably is a necessary requirement for many wearable technology and Internet of Things applications, as well as for many exciting next-generation healthcare models. Specifically, the ability to know the position and movement of various parts of the body can be vital for applications like rehabilitation, sports medicine, and even everyday sensing like monitoring seated spinal posture or respiration. A key challenge to detecting this kind of whole-body movement is the need to distribute sensors over the whole body surface without compromising comfort or wearabilitiy. 

In this collaborative project, we explored the problem from two directions: by developing soft, garment-integrated textile sensors that can detect joint positions through structures that look and feel like everyday clothing (University of Minnesota led this effort) and by developing computational algorithms capable of dealing with the complexity of different-sized bodies and a variety of sensor types while retaining the ability to accurately detect specific activities and qualities of movement (Virginia Tech led this effort). We validated our sensors and systems through many applications: sensing spinal posture for everyday seated postures as well as clinical conditions like kyphosis, sensing knee movements (both healthy and unhealthy), sensing breathing to monitor the respiratory health of smokers, and sensing healthy whole-body lifting postures for workers lifting large loads. In each case, we considered the relationship between the accuracy of the sensing method and the design tradeoffs for the wearable system. A loosely-fitted system is in many cases more comfortable for the wearer but less accurate for the clinician. By establishing the boundaries of useful accuracy under various conditions, designers of consumer and medical wearable products can make better, more informed decisions to build useful but wearable devices. 

Our project relied on contributions and participation from students from a wide range of disciplinary backgrounds: apparel design, electrical engineering, computer science, and human factors engineering. Sensors developed through this project were the basis for undergraduate projects and graduate theses/dissertations. We worked with collaborators at Johnson Space Center and at the University of Alabama, as well as cilincal partners in the University of Minnesota Medical School and the Sister Kenny Rehabilitation Hospital Research Center.
